messages: df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:17): i posted this on #html earlier but this seems like a good place to ask as well
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:17): can anyone explain to me why it is important that html files are human-readable?
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:17): it seems to me like it's a waste of bandwidth
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:17): the same is true for all sgml's, xml included. but perhaps i just don't understand the reason yet

d489ff1b992e28e05d7edc148195f283 (08:23): Because they're markup languages designed to be platform-independent and human editable in a text editor?  You could use a compressor tool to shrink down a final product for distribution though.

df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:26): d489ff1b992e28e05d7edc148195f283: fair enough but wouldn't it have made more sense to devise someththing else for distribution? i don't think browsers commonly support gzipped html, for instance

df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:27): d489ff1b992e28e05d7edc148195f283: i guess what i'm saying is... hadn't it made more sense to have had something like a HTML compiler that produces something more suitable for machines?
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:27): i'm sorry if my english is not very good

d489ff1b992e28e05d7edc148195f283 (08:28): Well gzip seems well supported in my experience, but I was referring to tools that regenerate a source file, such as HTML or ECMAScript with compression techniques, like shrinking variable names.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (08:28): every browser supports HTTP compression.
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:29): so there's no real advantage, except for the commodity of being human readable, right?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (08:29): that's a massive advantage.
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:29): in other words, it wouldn't make sense for an application to be based on a SGML-like document if the human never interacted with said document_
d489ff1b992e28e05d7edc148195f283 (08:29): Well, compiling the source would take away it's ability to be platform independent.
d489ff1b992e28e05d7edc148195f283 (08:30): And yes, human readability is a big bonus.

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (08:30): "compiling" it is a huge cost: you still have to specify the human-readable source, but you also have to define a compiled format on top of it, and then maintain both formats in sync--for very little benefit
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:31): i know the overhead for parsing a sgml document can't be very big but it somehow doesn't feel right to me to waste resources :)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (08:32): developing and speccing a compiled format, which every browser would have to support, and every web server would have to support, would be wasting resources
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (08:32): most pages are not bandwidth-limited by HTML.
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:34): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: i agree with you. just trying to understand the historical perspective
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:34): in the past, it would have been less painful
d489ff1b992e28e05d7edc148195f283 (08:34): I really don't see any advantage to a compiled form, maybe in the 90s..
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:34): d489ff1b992e28e05d7edc148195f283: some embedded devices, perhaps. and (very) low connectivity
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:35): that's all i really have in mind
df5bdf9a9bc790bc71dbb60569c5e62a (08:35): but i guess i got my question answered so thanks :)
